topic.title: Guidelines for panel-level help short descriptions
topic.shortdesc: Always use the <shortdesc> element in a panel-level help topic. The short description must make sense both as the opening text of the topic and as pop-up text over a related link.

prolog.author: Guidelines owner: Michelle Carey, from Content Workgroup

body.p: Panel-level help topics describe how to use windows, notebooks, panels, or tabs to complete a user task. Panel-level help topics might also describe fields, other objects on the user interface, or summary information.

section.title: Length
section.p: Use one to three sentences or up to 50 words.

section.title: What to say
section.p: Mention what task or tasks users can perform in the window or panel.

p.b: Example of an ineffective short description

dlentry.dd: Displays property attributes for an existing cube hierarchy.

section.p: This short description does not tell users what task or tasks this window will help them do. If users can change cube hierarchy properties, the short description should say that. Users are interested in completing tasks, not in product function. This short description is also a sentence fragment.

p.b: Example of an effective short description

dlentry.dd: Use this window to view and modify properties for an existing cube hierarchy.

section.p: The effective short description tells users what they can do in this window (view and modify properties).

section.title: Phrasing
section.p: Use the following phrasing: Use this window [or panel] to do taskA . . . . For windows that provide only information and do not require user actions, use the following phrasing: This window [or panel] shows . . . . Do not use sentence fragments.

section.title: Examples of effective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. Highlighting in a short description will not appear in the pop-up text over a related link. DB2 Administration Tool Menu panel
Use this panel to do administration tasks such as querying the catalog and providing users access to the database.
Preferences window
Use this window to specify how to display the shape parent name, the compartment titles, and the stereotype and visibility styles for shapes on the diagram surface. These settings will apply to all of the new shapes that you add in the model.
Archive Specification History panel
This panel shows the results of an existing archive specification by version.
User Preferences: Mail window
Use this window to select a default address book, to change how you save sent mail, to specify how you forward and receive mail automatically, or specify how to refresh your Inbox.

section.title: Examples of ineffective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. DB2 Administration Tool Menu panel This panel is the main menu in DB2 Admin.
This short description does not tell users what information the panel provides or what tasks they can do in this panel.
Device Bay window The device bay for your system can be enabled in two ways. You can change these settings at any time.
This short description is too vague to be helpful, and it does not follow the phrasing convention. This short description should name the two ways the device can be enabled without necessarily describing them in detail. The idea that users can change the settings later does not need to be placed so prominently in the topic (in the short description).
Databases panel Displays information about the databases that you selected.
This short description is a sentence fragment.
Manage Organizations window From here, you can manage organizations.
This short description does not follow the phrasing guideline: Use this window to . . . . This short description should also provide more information about how to manage organizations. Users might not understand what it means to manage an organization if they see this help topic out of context.
Monitor Collections window The Monitor Collections window checks the status of the following components:
Avoid adding a list or table lead-in sentence to a short description. You cannot add an <ol> or <ul> element inside a short description element. If you add a list or table lead-in sentence and then add the list or table to the next available element, the list or table will not be logically associated with the <shortdesc> element. Such a structure is semantically incorrect. You will not be able to reuse the list or table with its lead-in sentence. This short description will not make sense in pop-up text for a related link. Also, a window cannot check status. Users must check status.
